intro: Condea macvaughii, commonly known as the MacVaugh's condea, is a rare flowering plant native to the southwestern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, white to yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky, well-drained soils in arid or semi-arid environments. It is known for its compact growth habit and is often found in open woodlands or along streambanks. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a species of conservation concern.
